Intellectual Property Process
Intellectual Property Process

What is a Patent
What is a Patent
page.normal_text:
Purpose:
Purpose:

To promote the progress of science and useful arts… (U.S. Constitution Article I, §8, Clause 8)
To promote the progress of science and useful
arts… (U.S. Constitution Article I, §8, Clause 8)

System:
System:

A quid pro quo; Disclosure of the invention to the government in specific terms, in exchange for exclusive rights to the inventor
A quid pro quo;
Disclosure of the invention to the government
in specific terms, in exchange for exclusive
rights to the inventor

page.title:
Who Enforces Patent Infringements
Who Enforces Patent Infringements
page.normal_text:
Infringement: Violation of any of the patent rights
Infringement: Violation of any of the patent rights

Enforcement: Up to patent owner, not USPTO.
Enforcement: Up to patent owner, not USPTO.

The USPTO-granted rights valid only in U.S.
The USPTO-granted rights valid only in U.S.

PCT : Enables a U.S. applicant to file an international utility patent application in a standardized format at USPTO. A filing system; and it does not grant a patent
PCT : Enables a U.S. applicant to file an international utility
patent application in a standardized format at USPTO.
A filing system; and it does not grant a patent

Patentable & Non-patentable subject matters
Patentable & Non-patentable
subject matters
page.normal_text:
Patentable subject matters: “… any new and useful process, machine, manufacture, or composition of matter, or any new and useful improvement thereof… Software and business methods also patentable
